int-org-block.p: The Office of the High Commissioner, established by the UN General Assembly in December 1950 (initially with a three-year mandate to address the needs of refugees in Europe displaced by the Second World War), provides assistance and international protection to refugees and to internally displaced persons, and seeks durable solutions to their problems.

int-org-section.heading: Organization
int-org-section.p: The High Commissioner is elected by the UN General Assembly, and is responsible to the General Assembly and to the UN Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC). The High Commissioner is supported by a Deputy High Commissioner; an Assistant High Commissioner for Protection (who manages the division on International Protection, and a co-ordination team and a multi-stakeholder engagement team supporting the Global Compact on Refugees); and an Assistant High Commissioner for Operations (who oversees divisions of Emergency, Security and Supply; and Resilience and Solutions; the seven Regional Bureaux; the Principal Adviser on Internal Displacement, and the Special Adviser on Climate Action).

int-org-section.heading: Executive Committee
int-org-section.p: The Executive Committee of the High Commissioner's Programme (ExCom), established by ECOSOC, meets once a year (75th session: October 2024), and during the period October 2023-October 2024 comprised representatives of 108 states. ExCom gives the High Commissioner policy directives regarding material assistance programmes and advice on international protection. In addition, it oversees UNHCR's general policies and use of funds. A Standing Committee meets throughout the year to support ExCom’s activities.

int-org-section.heading: Administration
int-org-section.p: The Office of the High Commissioner includes an Executive Office (comprising an Ethics Office, Evaluation Office, Global Data Service, Governance Service, the New York Liaison Office, and the Special Adviser on Development); and an Inspector General’s Office; Office of the Director for Change; Principal Communications Adviser; Special Envoy for the Central Mediterranean Situation; Joint UNHCR-IOM Special Representative for Venezuelan Refugees and Migrants; and Special Envoy for the Horn of Africa. There is also a Principal Adviser on Displacement; Special Adviser on Climate Action; and seven Regional Bureaux—covering the Americas: based in Panamá, Panama; Asia and the Pacific: Bangkok, Thailand; East Africa and the Horn of Africa: Nairobi, Kenya; Europe: Geneva; Middle East and North Africa: Amman, Jordan; Southern Africa: Pretoria, South Africa; and West and Central Africa: Dakar, Senegal).
A Special Envoy for the Horn of Africa is attached to the Executive Office.
A Special Envoy for the Central Mediterranean Situation is attached to the Executive Office.
A UNHCR-IOM Joint Special Representative for Venezuelan Refugees and Migrants is attached to the Executive Office.

In 2024 UNHCR was active in 138 countries, and employed 18,879 staff, of whom 87% were field-based. UNHCR Global Service Centres, based in Budapest (Hungary), Copenhagen (Denmark), and Amman (Jordan), provide administrative support to the headquarters.

int-org-section.heading: Activities
int-org-section.p: The competence of the High Commissioner extends to any person who, owing to well-founded fear of war, violence or persecution, is outside the country of his or her nationality; to stateless people; and to internally displaced persons (IDPs—with similar needs to those of refugees but who have not crossed an international border) or those who are threatened with displacement. IDPs include—in addition to conflict-affected populations—people displaced by situations of general violence, human rights violations, natural or human-made disasters or environmental degradation. UNHCR aims to address the fundamental causes of refugee flows, and has urged recognition and comprehension of the broad patterns of global displacement and migration, and of the mixed nature of many 21st century population flows, which often comprise economic migrants, refugees, asylum seekers and victims of trafficking requiring detection and support.

In the UN system UNHCR is lead co-ordinator in refugee emergencies. Within the UN’s overall Cluster Approach to co-ordinate an international response to humanitarian disasters, UNHCR is the lead agency for Protection, and in conflict situations the Office leads the clusters on Camp Co-ordination and Camp Management (CCCM) (the International Organization for Migration —IOM—leads that cluster in natural disaster situations), and on Shelter (with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies leading in natural disaster situations).

At 31 December 2022 the total population of concern to UNHCR, based on provisional figures, amounted to 112.6m., compared with 94.7m. in the previous year, and with 33.9m. in 2010. The total number of people forcibly displaced as a result of persecution, conflict or other violence amounted to 108.4m. by the end of 2022, including 35.3m. refugees and people in refugee-like situations (of whom 29.4m. came under UNHCR’s mandate, and 5.9m. Palestinians under the mandate of the UN Relief and Works Agency —UNRWA), 62.5m. IDPs, and 5.4m. asylum seekers. UNHCR was also concerned with 6m. recently returned refugees and IDPs, 4.4m. stateless persons, and 5.2m. others deemed to require the Office’s protection or assistance.

The states hosting the most refugees (or people in refugee-like situations) at end-2022 were Türkiye (3.6m.), Iran (3.4m.), Colombia (2.5m.—including others in need of international protection), Germany (2.1m.), and Pakistan (1.7m.). As at 31 December 2022 Aruba was hosting the largest number of refugees relative to its national population (one in six), owing to an influx of people fleeing socioeconomic turmoil in Venezuela, followed by Lebanon (one in seven, mainly Syrian, refugees), Curaçao (one in 14, mainly Venezuelans), Jordan (one in 16), and Montenegro (1 in 19).

The Office noted that 76% of refugees and other people in need of international protection in 2022 were hosted by low- and middle-income countries that were already under severe economic pressure, and that least developed countries were hosting one-fifth of the global total of refugees.
As at the end of 2022 more than one-half (52%) of all refugees and other people in need of international protection originated from only three countries: Syria, Ukraine and Afghanistan.

In September 2016 a UN high-level Summit on Addressing Large Movements of Refugees and Migrants adopted the New York Declaration for Refugees and Migrants. Several commitments were made therein that aimed to ensure the rights and safety of refugees, acknowledging in particular the vulnerability of women and children, and the risks posed by trafficking and forced labour. The Office was tasked with leading a broad consultative process to formulate a Global Compact on Refugees. This was eventually adopted by the UN General Assembly in December 2018, and had four principal objectives: to relieve the pressure on refugee hosting countries; to enhance refugee self-reliance; to expand access to third-country solutions; and to support conditions in refugees’ countries of origin to enable safe, dignified returns. It incorporated a Comprehensive Refugee Response Framework, already approved as an annex to the New York Declaration, which aimed to strengthen the resilience of host communities. It also defined a Programme of Action to support host countries and refugees, determined that a ministerial Global Refugee Forum (GRF) would be convened periodically, and proposed the establishment of multi-stakeholder Support Platforms to address specific refugee situations.
The second GRF was convened in December 2023, in Geneva (the first having been held in December 2019). Financial commitments estimated at US $2,200m. were made during the event.

From 2021 UNHCR introduced a results-based `COMPASS’ strategic management approach, which aimed to support the implementation of the Global Compact on Refugees and of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs); some 52 core indicators were incorporated into the COMPASS approach, to measure related progress. Under COMPASS UNHCR’s country plans were to be more efficiently aligned with those of partner agencies and of national governments, with a focus on including refugees and stateless people in national health and education systems, social security and job creation initiatives, and in local development and peacebuilding programmes. UNHCR has advocated for the inclusion of populations of concern in COVID-19 vaccination campaigns. It focuses operational programming the following impact areas: Protect, Respond, Empower, and Solve.
The Office maintains an online population statistics database. World Refugee Day, sponsored by UNHCR, is held annually on 20 June.

int-org-section.heading: International Protection
int-org-section.p: In the exercise of its mandate UNHCR seeks to ensure that refugees and asylum seekers are protected against refoulement (forcible return); that they receive asylum; and that they are treated according to internationally recognized standards. The Office discourages the detention and encampment of refugees and asylum seekers, as this restricts their freedom of movement and opportunities to become self-reliant. UNHCR supervises the application of, and actively encourages states to accede to, the 1951 UN Convention relating to the Status of Refugees (with 146 parties at January 2024) and its 1967 Protocol (which had 147 parties at that time). These define the rights as well as the duties of refugees and contain provisions that address a variety of matters that affect their day-to-day lives. The treatment of refugees is also guided by a number of instruments adopted at regional level. UNHCR works in countries of origin and of asylum to ensure that policies, laws and practices comply with international commitments, and seeks to facilitate swift, just asylum procedure systems.

UNHCR prioritizes the specific needs of refugee women, children, and elderly refugees in its programme planning and implementation. The Office actively seeks solutions to support refugees residing in urban areas (representing more than three-fifths of all refugees). In June 2011 UNHCR issued an updated strategy on Action against Sexual and Gender-Based Violence. A UNHCR Framework for the Protection of Children was adopted in 2012. Since 2017 UNHCR has reported on the number of unaccompanied and separated children in refugee populations, and from 2018 the Office urged national governments to follow suit. In 2022 there were 51,700 new asylum applications from unaccompanied or separated children (compared with 21,000 in the previous year).
UNHCR has attempted to address the issue of military attacks on refugee camps through the promotion of a set of principles aimed at ensuring refugee safety.
As a co-sponsor of the Joint UN Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS), UNHCR promotes access for displaced populations to HIV/AIDS prevention services, treatment and care.

In November 2014 UNHCR initiated a 10-year global action plan focused on ending statelessness (lack of legal nationality). The Office promotes new accessions to the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Stateless Persons (which had 96 states parties at January 2024) and to the 1961 Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness (with 79 states parties at that time).

UNHCR has criticized a trend by governments to withdraw citizenship from certain captured foreign terrorist fighters and their families (those believed to be eligible for dual or multiple citizenships), thereby rendering many in effect stateless.

int-org-section.heading: Assistance Activities
int-org-section.p: In the early stages of a crisis UNHCR conducts an initial assessment to ascertain the scale of response required and immediate critical requirements. Rapid assessments are undertaken next to identify key priorities for intervention and to estimate total resource requirements. UNHCR uses existing data to accelerate its crisis assessments. The subsequent pattern of operations is as follows: emergency planning (in complex emergencies a UNHCR-led inter-agency Refugee Response Plan is organized); implementation; monitoring; reporting; and evaluation. The Office’s assistance can take various forms, including the provision of shelter/non-food items (NFIs—for example household goods, jerry cans, sleeping mats and blankets; also referred to as core relief items—CRIs), clean water, sanitation, medical care, education, and counselling; supporting asylum applications; and facilitating refugee registration. UNHCR has developed a Biometric Identity Management System (BIMS), which swiftly registers and verifies refugees’ identities, using iris scans, fingerprints and digital photographs, and gathers detailed social background information on education, skills, etc.

As far as possible, assistance is geared towards the identification and implementation of durable solutions to refugee problems. These generally take one of three forms: voluntary repatriation; local integration; or resettlement onwards to a third country. Where voluntary repatriation, generally the preferred solution, is feasible, the Office assists refugees to overcome obstacles preventing their return to their country of origin. This may be done through negotiations with governments involved, and by arranging transport for and providing basic assistance packages to repatriating refugees, and also by implementing or supporting local integration or reintegration programmes in their home countries, including Quick Impact Projects (QIPs) aimed at income generation and at the restoration of local infrastructures. Similarly, the Office works to enable local communities to support returned IDPs. Some 339,300 refugees repatriated voluntarily to their home countries (numbering 38) in 2022. When voluntary repatriation is not an option, efforts are made to assist refugees to integrate locally and to become self-supporting in their countries of asylum. Assistance in procuring accommodation may be offered, as well as the provision of skills training, or of loans. In cases where resettlement through emigration is the only viable solution to a refugee problem, UNHCR negotiates with governments to obtain suitable resettlement opportunities, to encourage liberalization of admission criteria, and to draft special immigration schemes. Some 114,300 refugees were resettled to third countries in 2022, representing a significant increase over the total in 2021 (57,500).

int-org-section.heading: The Americas
int-org-section.p: Since 1984 a major regional meeting on refugees and displaced persons has been convened at 10-yearly intervals. Gathered in Cartagena, Colombia, in November 1984, 10 Latin American heads of state and of government adopted the (non-binding) Cartagena Declaration on Refugees and Displaced Persons, which somewhat extended the definition of `refugee’ beyond that provided for under the 1951 Convention, to include, for example, people fleeing severe generalized violations of human rights. (In mid-2019 UNHCR welcomed the first practical application of the expanded definition—by Brazil, which granted refugee status at that time to Venezuelans, with no criminal record, who had sought refuge from their home country’s profound socioeconomic crisis.)

In December 2014 UNHCR and regional governments, convened in Brasília, Brazil, adopted the Brazil Declaration, comprising a co-operation framework and related plan of action to guide activities relating to the protection of refugees, displaced and stateless persons in Latin America and the Caribbean during the period 2015-24. The plan of action comprised 11 strategic programmes, including a new initiative focused on maintaining borders as areas of safety and protection. In February 2018 a meeting of regional stakeholders, held in Brasília, adopted a document, `100 points of Brasília’, which represented the region’s contribution to the Global Compact on Refugees that was endorsed by the UN General Assembly later in the year.

The political and socioeconomic crisis that escalated in Venezuela from 2015 prompted an increasingly large-scale population movement. There were also pendular movements of people who had to cross borders to meet basic needs, and an outflow from Venezuela of returnees to their countries of origin. A number of impromptu refugee camps arose at the Colombia-Venezuela border, notably in the Colombian city of Cúcuta. By 30 November 2023 there were reported to be 7.7m. Venezuelan migrants, asylum seekers and refugees, of whom 6.5m. were residing in host countries in Latin America and the Caribbean, including 2.9m. in Colombia, 1.5m. in Peru, 510,500 in Brazil, 474,900 in Ecuador, 444,400 in Chile, 217,700 in Argentina, and 124,100 in the Dominican Republic. By 30 June 2023 there were 300,759 recognized Venezuelan refugees globally (of whom 134,600 were in Spain and 89,300 were in Brazil), and 1,184,889 pending asylum claims submitted by Venezuelans (including 532,700 in Peru and 455,500 in the USA). Some countries—for example participants in MERCOSUR ’s regional visa system—had specific residency procedures in place for Venezuelans that were outside the asylum system, facilitating their socioeconomic integration through access to formal jobs and services (including to national vaccination campaigns). Nearly 4.5m. residence and regular stay permits had been granted to Venezuelans by August 2023.

In September 2018 a Joint UNHCR- IOM Special Representative was appointed to address the Venezuelan crisis and its impact on the region, and a Regional Inter-agency Co-ordination Mechanism (`RV4’) was established to facilitate a coherent operational response. By 2024 this had more than 200 participating organizations. An 18-point Quito Declaration on the Human Mobility of Venezuelan Citizens was signed in September 2018 by 11 Latin American governments; a supporting plan of action was adopted in November, and technical meetings of the so-called `Quito Process’ have been convened regularly. In July 2019, within the framework of the Quito Process, UNHCR and IOM issued a roadmap towards reinforcing co-operation, communication and co-ordination between countries of migrant transit and destination in the region; enhancing measures aimed at deterring people-smuggling and trafficking; and protecting the most vulnerable migrants by combating discrimination, xenophobia and sexual and gender-based violence. At that time regional governments agreed to support the use of an Information Card for Regional Mobility, in support of documentation and registration processes at national level.

From March 2020, however, in view of the COVID-19 pandemic, strict preventive restrictions were imposed on borders throughout the region, as well as prolonged national lockdown measures and domestic curbs on mobility, which adversely impacted the capacity of refugees and migrants to sustain their livelihoods and to access basic goods and services. Subsequently pendular movements of Venezuelan migrants and refugees reprised, while some refugees and migrants chose to repatriate to Venezuela.

In February 2021 UNHCR and IOM welcomed a decision by the Colombian authorities to issue a formal 10-year Temporary Protection Status (TPS) to Venezuelan migrants, thereby stabilizing their circumstances and enabling their access to rights and services. A UNHCR-IOM-led regional Refugee and Migrant Response Plan (RMRP) for 2023-24 aimed to assist, through protection, humanitarian, and socioeconomic integration activities, around 3.4m. people—including migrants in transit, those making pendular movements between Venezuela and Colombia, Colombian returnees, and members of host communities receiving Venezuelan refugees. During 2024 the RMRP required funding of US $1,587m. from the international community.

Following the conclusion in 2016 of a final peace accord between the Colombian Government and the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC, the largest Colombian rebel group), the High Commissioner stated that UNHCR would continue to respond to internal displacement in Colombia, and would focus in particular on the integration of Indigenous communities and other marginal groups. Subsequently, owing to a continuing insurgency by the rebel grouping Ejército De Liberación Nacional (ELN) and other parallel militant and criminal activity, waves of displacement persisted. At 28 February 2023 some 6,834,492 Colombian IDPs who had been displaced since 1985 were of concern to UNHCR, including 922,591 Colombian refugees who had been uprooted since the 2016 peace accord, and 214,739 who had been newly displaced in 2022. In many cases IDPs resided in informal settlements under the control of militia. UNHCR monitors civilians in communities that are under threat from the presence of armed militants, and implements local initiatives aimed at promoting socioeconomic inclusion and at preventing xenophobia.

Increasing unrest in El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras (`the Northern Triangle’) has in recent years led to significant forced population movements, particularly towards Mexico and the USA. At 31 December 2022 there were 953,279 people of concern to UNHCR within Central America and Mexico, including 398,275 refugees and asylum seekers, and some 318,590 IDPs in El Salvador and Honduras. Crime and violence rooted in economic and food insecurity, and associated with climate change (i.e. an intensification of both rains and drought in the Central American `dry corridor’) were reported to be the principal causes of the displacement. In July 2016 UNHCR and the Organization of American States (OAS) co-chaired a high-level roundtable meeting, in San José, Costa Rica, attended by government representatives of seven Central American countries, Canada and the USA, to address the situation of people fleeing the Northern Triangle. The meeting agreed a series of comprehensive, collaborative actions—issued in the following month as the San José Action Statement—including enhancing protection measures in countries of origin, and the provision of international protection for asylum seekers and refugees. A Joint UNHCR-OAS Technical Secretariat, activated in 2018, supports the Comprehensive Regional Protection and Solutions Framework (Marco Integral Regional para la Protección y Soluciones—MIRPS), which was established in 2017, to promote the rights of migrants and refugees from or transiting through Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico and Panama. Under MIRPS, each country pursues a national action plan and forms strategic alliances with local authorities, civil society, private sector interests, multilateral organizations, and other states, to address the needs of displaced persons and the communities hosting them. A Support Platform for MIRPS, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, France, Italy, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the USA and the EU, was established in December 2019, and in May 2020 a MIRPS Fund was launched. In January 2024 the sixth MIRPS annual meeting approved a MIRPS Statutory Charter. In Central America UNHCR assists IDPs, and works to strengthen national asylum systems and to promote the integration of refugees into host communities.

During 2021-early 2024 unprecedented numbers of USA-bound migrants and asylum seekers gathered in northern Mexico, driven by, inter alia, the socioeconomic collapse in Venezuela, violent instability in Haiti, a political crackdown in Nicaragua, and violence in Ecuador. In May 2023 the US Administration of President Joe Biden introduced new legislation requiring migrants and people seeking international protection in the USA to pre-book scheduled appointments (numbering 1,450 daily as at July) with the US customs and border protection agency—via a smartphone app—prior to approaching the border. Nevertheless, some 302,000 border encounters were made in December (compared with a monthly average of 39,000 during 2013-19). In August 2023 UNHCR stated concern that many arrivals at the southern US border did not have access to information or legal support that would best guide their decision making. The agency stated its willingness to work with the US and other national authorities to ensure that safe pathways were in place for asylum seekers. During 2024 UNHCR and IOM were supporting a US Safe Mobility initiative, that aimed to expand legal routes to the USA for refugees and migrants from South and Central America.

UNHCR provides counselling and legal services for asylum seekers in Canada and the USA, and supports the integration of resettled refugees in both countries (both major resettlement destinations). At 31 December 2022 the estimated refugee populations totalled 140,621 in Canada and 363,059 in the USA, while asylum seekers numbered 113,066 and 1,798,792, respectively. Canada received 47,000 resettlement arrivals in that year (of whom 45% originated in Afghanistan), and the USA 29,000.

int-org-section.heading: Central and South-Eastern Europe
int-org-section.p: In November 2011 the ministers responsible for foreign affairs of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Montenegro and Serbia, having been assisted by UNHCR to develop a binding common commitment to address the region’s protracted population displacement, issued a joint declaration that paved the way for the development of a Regional Housing Programme (RHP) to pursue housing solutions for vulnerable refugees and promote reconciliation in the region. By end-2023, when the RHP came to an end, housing units had been completed for 11,300 families. At 31 December 2022 there was still an estimated total Bosnian refugee population of 17,713, with the majority residing in Germany and Serbia. Also at the end of 2022 there were 96,305 IDPs of concern to UNHCR in Bosnia and Herzegovina, for whom UNHCR was seeking long-term solutions.

UNHCR has worked to strengthen asylum procedures in Kosovo and aims to implement durable solutions for the remaining IDPs and for people considering repatriation. UNHCR reported 29,321 voluntary minority returns during 2000-October 2023, including 12,762 Kosovo Serbs, 7,770 Kosovo Egyptians and Kosovo Ashkali, and 4,077 Kosovo Roma. At the end of 2022 there were still more than 200,000 Kosovars in need of durable solutions in the western Balkans (mainly Serbia), and there were 15,646 IDPs within Kosovo.

Some 26,521 refugees from Croatia (principally) and Bosnia and Herzegovina were hosted in Serbia at 31 December 2022. UNHCR has expanded its durable solution programmes for IDPs in Serbia, by assisting with the construction of social housing, by providing cash grants to help people to move to the new accommodation, and by organizing self-reliance projects.

UNHCR’s 2024 Regional Refugee Response Plan for the Ukraine situation, issued in February, required US $1,100m. to fund operations, in collaboration with 313 partners, in: Bulgaria (accommodating 72,775 Ukrainian refugees under temporary protection at 8 March 2024), Czech Republic (381,400, at 31 January), Estonia (38,020, at 2 March), Hungary (66,135, at 17 March), Latvia (47,616, at 6 March), Lithuania (41,490, at 11 March), Moldova (116,855, at 31 March), Poland (956,635, at 15 December 2023), Romania (77,250, at 10 March 2024), and Slovakia (117,265 at 3 March). In the refugee-receiving countries UNHCR aimed to support the socioeconomic inclusion of refugees (particularly the most vulnerable), to provide protection services, to support access to nutrition, health, education and livelihoods, and to provide cash assistance for essential needs. The Plan was also to assist 55,000 members of host communities. As at 14 March 2024, in total, 5,982,900 Ukrainians were accommodated within Europe (around 4.4m. had temporary protection status) and 503,100 beyond Europe. There were 3,689,000 IDPs in Ukraine at 31 December 2023.

Throughout the region UNHCR is concerned to reduce and prevent statelessness, and to promote respect for the basic rights of stateless people. The Office has undertaken a civil registration programme for undocumented IDPs in Kosovo and Serbia, particularly members of Roma, Ashkali and Egyptian communities in Kosovo, deemed to be at risk of statelessness. As at 31 December 2022 70,594 people in Estonia and 187,564 in Latvia were registered as stateless; in each country ethnic Russians comprised the majority of the stateless population.

In June 2013 the European Union (EU) adopted a Common European Asylum System (CEAS), establishing common asylum standards for its member states; UNHCR has aimed to raise regional awareness of the CEAS, and also to support EU member states with incorporating CEAS standards into domestic legal frameworks.

In 2015 more than 1m. refugees and migrants crossed the Mediterranean into Europe, of whom some 850,000 travelled across the Aegean and Dodecanese seas from Turkey (known since June 2022 as Türkiye) into Greece. Most of the refugees and migrants landing in Greece were reported to be in transit, via the Western Balkans, towards Austria, Germany, and other destinations in Western and Northern Europe. From mid-2015 UNHCR deployed personnel to locations in the eastern Aegean, to advise and assist incoming refugees and to support unaccompanied children and other particularly vulnerable people. Nearly 600,000 migrants reportedly passed through Serbia during the second half of that year. Following the securing of the Hungary-Serbia frontier with a deterrent razor-wire fence, which was completed in October, the majority of migrants rerouted into Croatia, and once that country’s border controls had been tightened the Slovenia-Austria border became the focus of the migration route northwards. The construction of border fences was initiated in November by Slovenia, the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia—FYRM (now North Macedonia), and Austria. Meanwhile, Croatia, the FYRM, Serbia and Slovenia limited entry for Afghan, Iraqi and Syrian citizens. UNHCR supported the implementation of a 17-point plan of action agreed in October by EU and non-member state Balkan leaders as a framework for co-operation on managing the influx of refugees through the Balkans, and also advised on the construction of facilities at Reception and Identification Centres at locations experiencing a heavy influx of migrants and refugees. Meanwhile, UNHCR established Border Management and Protection of Refugees projects in Bulgaria, Hungary, Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia. These were undertaken on the basis of tripartite agreements between UNHCR, the relevant state authorities, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs). Under the projects, participating NGOs made regular visits to border crossings and detention centres to assess the situation of and provide legal advice to new arrivals; their findings were then reported onwards to the local border police and to UNHCR.

In March 2016 the Hungarian Government issued a decree that declared a `crisis situation due to mass immigration’. In March 2017 UNHCR stated deep concern at a decision by the Hungarian legislature that authorized the automatic mandatory detention in border camps of all asylum seekers. This was presented by the Hungarian authorities as a measure aimed at preventing terrorism, and, reportedly, also at protecting its traditionally Christianity-based culture and identity (the majority of asylum seekers being Muslim). In April the Office urged the EU to suspend temporarily asylum seeker returns to Hungary, pending the alignment of relevant policy and practice in that country with European and international law. In February 2018 UNHCR urged the Hungarian authorities to abandon proposed legislation that aimed to end the extension of support to asylum seekers by civil society and NGOs. UNHCR stated concern in June 2020 over the adoption in Hungary, in response to the COVID-19 emergency, of new legislation under which potential asylum seekers were—in contravention of the provisions of the 1951 Convention—to be refused entry at the Hungarian border and redirected to declare their intentions at a designated Hungarian diplomatic mission, thereby exposing them to the risk of refoulement. During 2016-21 more than 70,000 migrants were forcibly removed from Hungarian territory.

In March 2016 an EU-Turkey accord entered into effect that provided for failed asylum seekers, and migrants arriving post-20 March who did not apply for asylum in Greece, to be returned to Turkey. Among concessions offered to Turkey in return, EU member states were to resettle one Turkey-based Syrian refugee for every migrant returned to that country from Greece. In accordance with the agreement (to which UNHCR was not a party) former refugee reception centres were reclassified as detention facilities. In view of UNHCR’s opposition to mandatory detention, it suspended certain of its activities at the former centres, including the provision of transport. UNHCR personnel continued, however, to provide life-saving assistance at coastal locations, to undertake protection monitoring, to identify incomers with specific assistance needs, to offer counselling to new arrivals, and to provide information on rights and procedures. UNHCR and partners also continued to improve conditions in camps on the Greek mainland. From early 2017-September 2021 UNHCR administered an EU-funded cash assistance programme for Greece-based asylum seekers; responsibility for managing the initiative was assumed by the Greek Government on 1 October. In September 2020, following a period of heightened tensions, exacerbated by tight COVID-19-related restrictions on freedom of movement, the very overcrowded Moria camp on Lesbos was destroyed by fires that had been instigated by residents; significant numbers of asylum seekers were then moved to a temporary camp at Mavrovouni, also on Lesbos. In March 2021 the EU extended €250m. in funding to Greece for the construction of new refugee camps on five Aegean islands (Chios, Kos, Leros, Lesbos and Samos). A revised EU-Turkey statement, issued in March 2022, urged continued support for Syrian refugees in Turkey; intensified focus on the situation of Syrian IDPs in Syria; continued assistance to asylum seekers and refugees in Greece, including decent reception conditions on the Greek islands; increased returns to Turkey; the voluntary resettlement of significant numbers of refugees from Turkey into EU member states; and the implementation of swift high-standard asylum procedures and a credible monitoring mechanism. During the period 2016-May 2023 37,560 Syrians were resettled to the EU from Türkiye. It was reported in 2023 that Türkiye was no longer readmitting migrants returned from Greece.

Under a non-binding Memorandum of Understanding that was concluded in July 2023 between the EU and Tunisia—a favoured point of departure for migrants aiming to reach Italy—the EU was to extend budgetary support to Tunisia, and was to focus investment there on areas that included migration management (with an initial €105m. designated to combating people smuggling, prioritizing the local activities of UNHCR and IOM, and the provision of patrol vehicles and equipment). During two days alone in mid-September some 8,000 migrants who had departed from Tunisia landed on the Italian island of Lampedusa, which lies around 113 km from the Tunisian coast and 205 km from Sicily.

During 2023 292,985 irregular migrant arrivals in Europe were reported, the majority having landed by boat. Italy received 157,651 seaborne migrants, Greece 41,561, and Spain’s Canary Islands 39,910. UNHCR has supported refugee determination procedures and undertaken protection and resettlement activities in Italy, and assisted the Greek authorities in transferring authorized asylum seekers living in overcrowded, unsanitary and often dangerous conditions in reception camps on the Greek islands to urban accommodation or state-run shelters on the mainland and Crete. In 2022 881,220 first-time asylum seekers—principally from Syria (15% of the total), Afghanistan (12.9%), Venezuela (5.7%), Türkiye (5.6%) and Colombia (4.8%)—applied for international protection in EU member states: the highest total since 2015-16. (Asylum applications from Ukrainians represented only 2.8% of the total, as the majority of Ukrainians sheltering in nearby states had sought temporary protection status.) Some 40% of processed first-instance asylum claims were approved in that year (mostly those from applicants from Syria, Belarus, Ukraine, Eritrea, Yemen and Mali); more than one-half of the approvals were agreed by Germany and France.

int-org-section.heading: Central Asia
int-org-section.p: The Office's priorities in Central Asia have included protection of refugees and asylum seekers; ensuring the compliance of refugee status determination procedures with international standards, while also seeking durable solutions and promoting the self-reliance of refugees; preserving asylum space within mixed migratory flows; and preventing and reducing statelessness.

All member states of the Commonwealth of Independent States excepting Uzbekistan had acceded by 2024 to the 1951 UN Convention relating to the Status of Refugees. UNHCR has reported that compliance with the 1951 Convention is problematic in the Central Asia region, and that national preoccupations with perceived cross-border threats and domestic security have adversely impacted asylum policy and the protection of refugees. A regional ministerial conference that UNHCR helped to organize in March 2011 adopted the AlmatI Declaration, in which participants determined to establish a regional framework for co-operation in the efficient management of mixed migration flows and refugee issues. The resulting AlmatI Process on Refugee Protection and International Migration, headquartered in AlmatI, Kazakhstan, was initiated in September 2012. Its core countries are Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Türkiye and Turkmenistan.

In 2013 UNHCR supported the Tajik author­ities with the establishment of a modern refugee registration framework, and with revising national citizenship legislation. UNHCR has promoted ways to safeguard Tajikistan’s border management systems.

Statelessness in Central Asia largely relates to the situation of people whose nationality was not formally confirmed or who did not actively acquire a new nationality following the termination of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) in 1991.

UNHCR implemented a series of `Seeds for Solutions’ initiatives in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan during 2014-17, which aimed to address statelessness by registering the stateless population and providing assistance with citizenship determination and acquisition procedures. Legislation aimed at preventing reducing statelessness was developed in those countries during this period. At the end of 2022 the stateless population in Uzbekistan was recorded at 27,389.

Following the takeover of Afghanistan in August 2021 by the fundamentalist Taliban organization, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan—which all adjoin Afghanistan—were reported to have increased border security significantly. UNHCR has prioritized promoting legal and policy reforms in Central Asian countries, with the aim of enhancing access, fair asylum procedures, and social protection systems. As at 30 June 2023 13,025 Afghan asylum seekers had fled to Uzbekistan, and 8,164 to Tajikistan.

int-org-section.heading: Eastern Europe
int-org-section.p: The dissolution of the former USSR led to significant population relocation and displacement, and to a large number of stateless people in Eastern Europe. During 2003-10 more than 600,000 stateless people in the Russian Federation were given citizenship. At the end of 2022 there were 95,195 people registered as stateless in Russia, and 36,233 in Ukraine—where Roma people have reportedly been at heightened risk of statelessness.
Ethnic Russians represented a majority of the 187,564 people who were registered as stateless in Latvia as at 31 December 2022, and also of the then 68,111 stateless residents of Estonia.

UNHCR’s 2024 Regional Refugee Response Plan for the Ukraine situation, issued in February, required US $1,100m. to fund operations, in collaboration with 313 partners, in: Bulgaria (accommodating 72,775 Ukrainian refugees under temporary protection at 8 March 2024), Czech Republic (381,400, at 31 January), Estonia (38,020, at 2 March), Hungary (66,135, at 17 March), Latvia (47,616, at 6 March), Lithuania (41,490, at 11 March), Moldova (116,855, at 31 March), Poland (956,635, at 15 December 2023), Romania (77,250, at 10 March 2024), and Slovakia (117,265 at 3 March). In the refugee-receiving countries UNHCR aimed to support the socioeconomic inclusion of refugees (particularly the most vulnerable), to provide protection services, to support access to nutrition, health, education and livelihoods, and to provide cash assistance for essential needs. The Plan was also to assist 55,000 members of host communities. As at mid-March, in total, 5,982,900 Ukrainians were accommodated within Europe (around 4.4m. had temporary protection status) and 503,100 beyond Europe. There were 3,689,000 IDPs in Ukraine at 31 December 2023.

On 19 September 2023 Azerbaijan launched a major military offensive (framed as an anti-terrorist operation) aimed at disarming and forcing the removal of Armenian troops positioned in Nagornyi Karabakh. On the following day Azerbaijan claimed a `complete surrender’ by Karabakh Armenian combatants; a ceasefire was declared, and the disarmament of the defeated troops was subsequently organized. The Azerbaijani authorities declared that the rights of local ethnic Armenians (at that time numbering around 120,000) would be upheld. Nevertheless a significant rapid exodus from Nagornyi Karabakh into Armenia was reported: by September nearly 100,500 people were reported to have fled from the enclave. UNHCR teams and partners supported the Armenian authorities in establishing emergency registration and co-ordination mechanisms, and supplied NFIs, including emergency bedding, to incoming Karabakh Armenians.

UNHCR's activities in Azerbaijan have focused on strengthening the national asylum system and refugee legislation, and offering, in as far as possible, assistance to refugees under its mandate there who do not have a legal right to work. The Office welcomed a commitment by Azerbaijan to offer a health insurance package to people of concern from January 2020. UNHCR has advocated with the Armenian authorities to strengthen the national asylum system to support an ethnic Armenian refugee population—numbering up to 22,000 people at its peak—which, from 2011, had fled to Armenia to escape the Syrian civil war. UNHCR has supported the socioeconomic integration of people of concern in Armenia (including 672 stateless people as at end-2022), and has advocated for that population to be woven into the Armenian action plan aimed at achieving the UN Sustainable Development Goals. The Office estimated that at the end of 2022 the global refugee population of Armenian origin totalled 14,844, and that of Azerbaijani origin was 42,013. UNCHR reported that at 31 December 2022 Azerbaijan was supporting, in total, 658,793 IDPs.

There were 292,856 IDPs in Georgia at 31 December 2022. UNHCR has supported that country in strengthening and implementing its national legislative framework and action plans relating to populations of concern, and has focused on the local integration of the displaced population. With regard to the separatist territories of Georgia, the Office promotes livelihood opportunities to encourage self-reliance among returned IDPs in Abkhazia, but has no operational access to South Ossetia.
UNHCR engages closely with regional consultative processes including the Panel on Migration and Asylum of the EU Eastern Partnership, the Budapest Process and the Prague Process.

int-org-section.heading: East Asia and the Pacific
int-org-section.p: From late August 2017 a rapid large-scale exodus of Myanma Rohingya towards Bangladesh was prompted by a renewed outbreak of violent insecurity in Rakhine State, Myanmar, that reportedly included—in response to an attack by Rohingya militants against government forces on 25 August—the systematic destruction of villages by both the national security forces and by officially sanctioned vigilante groups. UNHCR declared the crisis a `Level 3’ (severe) emergency. Around three-quarters of the mass outflow of refugees from Myanmar were women and children. Most refugees were accommodated at camps in the south-eastern Cox’s Bazar region, including at the Kutupalong-Balukhali encampment which had been extended in late 2017 and had become the world’s largest refugee settlement. From September 2017 UNHCR undertook successive airlifts of essential NFIs to Cox’s Bazar, including shelter kits, sleeping mats, tarpaulins, solar lamps, mosquito nets, and winter clothing. UNHCR and other humanitarian agencies also co-operated in providing food rations, mobile medical assistance, mass immunization, water, sanitation and hygiene facilities, education, and psychological support, including to survivors of sexual and gender based violence. Cash was distributed by UNHCR to families accommodated at Kutupalong-Balukhali. The Office also provided support to the Bangladeshi Government to develop a refugee data management system, to improve local protection standards, and to construct a new road at Kutupalong. In May 2018 UNHCR, UNDP and the Myanmar Government signed an MOU on preparing the way for future safe refugee returns. In September, however, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights urged the Bangladesh authorities to stall plans to repatriate Rohingya refugees to Myanmar, warning that this would potentially endanger their lives and freedom. From December the Bangladeshi authorities relocated, in phases, successive contingents of Rohingya refugees to the remote and under-resourced Bay of Bengal island of Bhasan Char, to ease overcrowding in Cox’s Bazar; UNHCR provided CRIs and helped to co-ordinate assistance. Following a devastating fire at the Kutupalong-Balukali camp in March 2021, which resulted in at least 15 fatalities and numerous injuries, and the loss of or damage to at least 10,000 shelters, UNHCR, IOM and partner agencies extended critical emergency support, including through the provision of medical supplies to burns patients, urgent first aid, and psychosocial assistance. The Office worked to re-issue refugees’ damaged documentation. A massive fire that broke out in March 2023 at Cox’s Bazar was reported to have destroyed some 2,000 shelters. In early January 2024 UNHCR worked with the Bangladesh authorities and the IOM to support refugees displaced by a further fire in Cox’s Bazar which destroyed some 800 homes. In March UNHCR and partners issued a US $852.4m. Joint Response Plan to support Rohingya refugees sheltering in Cox’s Bazar and on Bhasan Char (numbering, respectively, 942,614 and 33,893 at 29 February) and some 346,000 people in host communities over the coming year to access protection services, drinkable water, food, shelter, health care, livelihood opportunities, education, and vocational technical skills training.

Violent unrest that followed a military coup perpetrated in Myanmar on 1 February 2021 prompted significant new internal displacement. UNHCR required US $95.6m. to fund its assistance operations within Myanmar in 2024, focused on meeting basic needs and on strengthening protection and displacement monitoring. UNHCR reported at 18 March 2024 that there were around 2,811,300 IDPs in Myanmar (including, as at 31 December 2023, 276,612 returned IDPs), and 632,789 stateless people (mainly Rohingya). From February 2021 a new exodus of Myanma refugees was reported, in particular to India and Thailand (hosting, respectively, 78,731 and 91,339 refugees, as at 30 June 2023).

At 31 December 2023 some 90,801 verified mainly ethnic Kayin (and also Kayah and Tanintharyi), refugees from Myanmar were sheltering in nine camps in Thailand close to the Thailand-Myanmar border (more than one-third were accommodated at the largest camp, Mae-La). Thailand had not, by 2024, ratified the 1951 Refugee Convention and it had not established highly functioning asylum procedures. Thailand was also, at that time, accommodating 5,213 urban refugees and asylum seekers, and more than 500,000 registered stateless people, who were denied official identity cards and access to state services, and were at increased risk of trafficking. UNHCR has supported stateless residents there with the preparation of citizenship applications. At 29 February 2024 it was reported that there were 187,020 UNHCR-registered refugees and asylum-seekers in Malaysia. Some 164,130 were reported to be from Myanmar, including 108,500 Rohingya and 25,430 of Chin ethnicity. Malaysia has not acceded to the 1951 Refugee Convention and lacks a legal framework for managing asylum cases. UNHCR has worked to improve the protection environment there; from August 2019, however, the Office was denied access to Malaysian immigration holding centres. At 31 December 2022 some 115,169 people in Malaysia were registered as stateless.

UNHCR’s Beijing Office provides registration, refugee status determination and practical support to refugees and asylum seekers in the Chinese capital. Although China has acceded to the 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees and to its 1967 Protocol, it has not as yet enacted comprehensive national legislation in support of their implementation. UNHCR has advocated for the accession of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region to the 1951 Refugees Convention. A `unified screening mechanism’ for the assessment of claims to protection from refoulement was initiated by the Hong Kong SAR authorities in March 2014. In December 2022 legislation was adopted in Hong Kong that enabled the expulsion of asylum seekers who were appealing rejected applications. As at March 2024 there were around 14,700 asylum seekers in the territory.
Some 26,811 people were registered as stateless in Viet Nam at 31 December 2022.

UNHCR endeavours to facilitate safe passage to the Republic of Korea (South Korea) for people who have fled from the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea) to other countries in the region. During 2022 67 North Koreans were reported to have defected. Some 192 voluntary repatriations from South Korea to North Korea were reported during 2010-mid-2022, and two forced repatriations (in November 2019). China routinely repatriates North Korean defectors, designating them as economic migrants, despite this being regarded as refoulement under international law and returned defectors being subjected to severe punishments by the North Korean state. In March 2014 a UN Commission of Inquiry censured China over this policy and urged that all collaboration with the North Korean security agencies in identifying and forcibly returning North Koreans should cease. China is, meanwhile, estimated to accommodate around 30,000-50,000 legally resident North Korean guest workers. It was reported in October 2023 that up to 600 North Korean defectors (mainly women) had recently been forcibly repatriated from China. Up to 2,000 North Koreans were reported to remain in detention in China and liable to refoulement.

At 12 January 2024 UNHCR reported that 145,300 people were displaced in the Mindanao region of the Philippines. In December 2022 the Philippines acceded to the 1961 Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness. At that time 118,120 people in the Philippines (including persons of Indonesian and Sama Bajau descent) were believed by the Office to be either stateless or at risk of statelessness.

With a view to deterring increasing mixed inflows of migrants and asylum seekers travelling by sea (so-called irregular maritime arrivals—IMAs) Australia in recent years adopted increasingly strict asylum legislation, policies and processes. Bilateral agreements in 2012 to transfer IMAs to camps in Nauru and Papua New Guinea (PNG) were criticized by UNHCR, which expressed its concern at the adequacy of protection standards for the detained transferees. UNHCR has advocated for non-discriminatory asylum practices, for broader domestic understanding of asylum and refugee issues in Australia and New Zealand, and for alternatives to the use of detention. Australia’s arrangement with PNG ended on 31 December 2021. In March 2022 Australia accepted an offer by New Zealand to resettle up to 450 refugees; this was to be implemented over a three-year period. Eligible migrants were to be screened by UNHCR.

The Bali Process on People Smuggling, Trafficking in Persons and Related Transnational Crime (Bali Process), launched in February 2002, with 45 participating states, comprises a series of UNHCR-supported initiatives that aim to raise awareness of people smuggling throughout the Asia-Pacific region; to promote the enactment of national legislation aimed at combating this; to address its root causes; to improve intelligence sharing and enhance co-operation among law enforcement and border agencies; and to support states in adopting best practices in asylum management. The eighth ministerial conference of the Bali Process, convened in February 2023, in Adelaide, Australia, concurrently with the third Bali Process Government and Business Forum, issued the 2023 Adelaide Strategy for Cooperation, focused on the following areas: law enforcement; stakeholder engagement; information sharing and public information campaigns; irregular migration and related transnational crime; border management; victim protection and migration management; returns and reintegration; and co-ordination and support.

A Regional Co-operation Framework (RCF), adopted in March 2011, aimed to strengthen regional collaboration in safeguarding the protection of refugees while simultaneously countering irregular population movements. In March 2016 a Bali Process ministerial review conference determined to establish an emergency response mechanism. This was activated for the first time in 2017 in the context of the mass influx into Bangladesh of Rohingya refugees from Myanmar.

int-org-section.heading: South Asia
int-org-section.p: In May 2012 a regional stakeholders’ conference on Afghanistan endorsed a `Solutions Strategy for Afghan Refugees’ (SSAR), negotiated during 2011 by UNHCR, Afghanistan, Iran and Pakistan, and based on the `pillars’ of voluntary repatriation, sustainable reintegration in Afghanistan, and support for refugee hosting communities.

On 16 August 2021, in view of the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan, UNHCR issued a formal non-return advisory, aimed at preventing forced returns (including of failed asylum seekers) to that country. Nevertheless, Iran reportedly deported more than 1m. undocumented Afghans throughout that year. By 30 June 2023 1,619,145 Afghan asylum seekers were reported to have fled their homeland since August 2021 (1m. to Iran, 600,000 to Pakistan, 13,020 to Uzbekistan, and 6,125 to Tajikistan). At 30 November 2023 5,305,978 Afghans abroad were of concern to UNHCR, of whom 3.4m. were in Iran, 1.9m. in Pakistan, 13,025 in Uzbekistan, and 8,164 in Tajikistan. UNHCR-assisted Afghan refugees in Iran (totalling around 750,000) had been issued with official `Amayesh’ identification cards, and Pakistan-based Afghan refugees with official biometric Proof of Registration (PoR) cards. In October 2023 the Pakistan authorities ordered all undocumented foreigners (believed to number 1.7m., many of whom were Afghani) to leave the country by 1 November (later extended to 29 February 2024). During the period 15 September 2023-7 March 2024 531,400 Afghans repatriated from Pakistan (including forced repatriations). The cumulative number of UNHCR-facilitated voluntary repatriations of Afghan refugees from Iran and Pakistan during March 2002-March 2024 totalled around 6.2m. Where possible UNHCR has provided returnees with a cash grant, equivalent to up to US $375 in 2024, to support transportation and to assist initial social integration, offered counselling on health, legal and social matters, and monitored their situation. Particular focus has been placed upon the situation of returnee women and on the prevention of gender-based violence, and on encouraging the return of professional workers, such as doctors and teachers. As at March 2024 3.3m. people remained displaced within Afghanistan.

An inter-agency Afghanistan Regional Refugee Response Plan being led by UNHCR during 2024 required funding of US $638.8m., and aimed to support 5.4m. Afghan refugees, 1.6m. other vulnerable Afghans, and 2.5m. members of host communities, in Iran and Pakistan. UNHCR has worked to promote the socioeconomic inclusion of Afghan refugees, while pursuing durable solutions.

p-alternates.p: From late August 2017 a rapid large-scale exodus of Myanma Rohingya towards Bangladesh was prompted by a renewed outbreak of violent insecurity in Rakhine State, Myanmar, that reportedly included—in response to an attack by Rohingya militants against government forces on 25 August—the systematic destruction of villages by both the national security forces and by officially sanctioned vigilante groups. UNHCR declared the crisis a `Level 3’ (severe) emergency. Around three-quarters of the mass outflow of refugees from Myanmar were women and children. Most refugees were accommodated in 33 camps in the south-eastern Cox’s Bazar region, including at the Kutupalong-Balukhali encampment which had been extended in late 2017 and had become the world’s largest refugee settlement. From September 2017 UNHCR undertook successive airlifts of essential NFIs to Cox’s Bazar, including shelter kits, sleeping mats, tarpaulins, solar lamps, mosquito nets, and winter clothing. UNHCR and other humanitarian agencies also co-operated in providing food rations, mobile medical assistance, mass immunization, water, sanitation and hygiene facilities, education, and psychological support, including to survivors of sexual and gender based violence. Cash was distributed by UNHCR to families accommodated at Kutupalong-Balukhali. The Office also provided support to the Bangladeshi Government to develop a refugee data management system, to improve local protection standards, and to construct a new road at Kutupalong. In May 2018 UNHCR, UNDP and the Myanmar Government signed an MOU on preparing the way for future safe refugee returns. In September, however, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights urged the Bangladesh authorities to stall plans to repatriate Rohingya refugees to Myanmar, warning that this would potentially endanger their lives and freedom. Under a joint refugee verification exercise implemented by UNHCR and the Bangladesh Government from mid-2018, verified Rohingya refugees aged 13 years and above were issued with identity cards. New restrictions on the Bangladesh camp-based refugees (including a curfew and the prohibition of mobile telephones) and a heightened military presence at their camps were reported following the murder of a local Bangladeshi man in August 2019. In early April 2020, in response to the COVID-19 emergency, the Cox’s Bazar area was placed under `complete lockdown’ by the Bangladeshi authorities. From early June monsoon-related landslides, flooding and heavy winds further adversely impacted local living conditions. From December the Bangladeshi authorities relocated, in phases, successive contingents of Rohingya refugees to the remote and under-resourced Bay of Bengal island of Bhasan Char, to ease overcrowding in Cox’s Bazar; UNHCR provided CRIs and helped to co-ordinate assistance. Following a devastating fire at the Kutupalong-Balukali camp in March 2021, which resulted in at least 15 fatalities and numerous injuries, and the loss of or damage to at least 10,000 shelters, UNHCR, IOM and partner agencies provided critical emergency support, including through the provision of medical supplies to burns patients, urgent first aid, and psychosocial assistance. The Office worked to re-issue refugees’ damaged documentation. A massive fire that broke out in March 2023 at Cox’s Bazar was reported to have destroyed some 2,000 shelters. In January 2024 UNHCR worked with the Bangladesh authorities and the IOM to support refugees displaced by a further fire in Cox’s Bazar which destroyed some 800 homes. In March UNHCR and partners issued a US $852.4m. Joint Response Plan to support Rohingya refugees sheltering in Cox’s Bazar and on Bhasan Char (numbering, respectively, 942,614 and 33,893 at 29 February) and some 346,000 people in host communities over the coming year to access protection services, drinkable water, food, shelter, health care, livelihood opportunities, education, and vocational technical skills training.

int-org-section.p: Violent unrest that followed a military coup perpetrated in Myanmar on 1 February 2021 prompted a renewed outflow of Myanma refugees, including to northeastern Mizoram, India. At 31 January 2024 India was hosting a UNHCR-assisted refugee population numbering 46,630.

In May 2009 the Sri Lankan Government terminated military operations against Tamil separatists, marking the end of a conflict that had in previous years caused significant population displacement. The largest camp for IDPs, Menik Farm, was closed in September 2012. From 2013 UNHCR shifted its priorities in Sri Lanka towards reintegration support, including the promotion of self-reliance for returnees. UNHCR advocates for the rights of all persons of concern, including by promoting civil documentation and land and property rights, and works towards resettlement solutions where appropriate. At 31 December 2022 there were still 8,540 registered IDPs of concern to UNHCR in Sri Lanka.

int-org-section.heading: Middle East and North Africa
int-org-section.p: In 2024 the Syrian refugee population was the largest under UNHCR’s mandate. A Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (`3RP’) for 2024, requiring some US $5,536m. in total funding, was being co-led by UNHCR and UNDP , and aimed to assist Syrians who had fled to neighbouring countries (at 14 March 2024 a total of 5,034,875 were registered with UNHCR), as well as stateless persons, and 3.5m. members of host communities. Of the total number of Syrian refugees, 279,585 were encamped, and the remainder in urban, peri-urban or rural situations. The 3RP is aligned with national emergency response plans. Some 3,136,353 Syrian refugees were registered in Türkiye (the highest number of refugees being hosted by any single country), while some 784,884 were registered in Lebanon, 639,552 in Jordan, 273,258 in Iraq, and 155,825 in Egypt. A further 45,003 exiled Syrians in North Africa were of concern to UNHCR (at 31 December 2022). UNHCR’s activities in the host countries have included providing refugees with shelter, cash grants and access to health and education; protection monitoring and outreach; field assessments; exploring resettlement opportunities, especially for the most vulnerable people of concern; and supporting the authorities and host communities with a view to mitigating the impact of refugee influxes. In May 2023 UNHCR, UNICEF and the WFP issued the results of a 10th annual joint Vulnerability Assessment of Syrian Refugees in Lebanon survey (VASyr) , which, based on an analysis of more than 5,000 refugee households in mid-2022, reported that 93% of Syrian refugee families in Lebanon were borrowing to cover the costs of essential food (which had risen by 332% since mid-2021) and non-food items; 46% were borrowing to pay for accommodation; and 35% to cover medication costs. Only 17% of Syrian refugees in Lebanon held legal residency; and 22% of refugee girls aged 15-19 were married (68% of these were not attending schools). The UNHCR presence in Jordan supports the management of the overcrowded Za'atri refugee camp, in the north of the country. At 31 July 2023 Za’atri and the nearby town of Mafraq were accommodating 169,043 registered Syrian refugees. The majority of Syrian refugees in Jordan were, however, based outside camps. UNHCR has targeted protection and support interventions at Syrian refugees living, often in substandard conditions, outside camps in Iraq (accounting for around three-fifths of all Syrian refugees in that country), and at their host communities; has provided outreach support to Syrian refugees in urban situations; and has monitored the provision of essential assistance and services in refugee camps (the largest of which, a complex near Dahuk, Kurdistan, was accommodating 78,475 Syrian refugees at 29 February 2024). From January 2016 the Turkish author­ities permitted many Syrian refugees registered in that country to apply for work permits. Increasing numbers of Afghans, Iranians and Iraqis were also reported to have applied for asylum in Türkiye in recent years. UNHCR’s activities in Türkiye have focused on enhancing the protection environment; registration and profiling; status determination; facilitating resettlement to third countries; community support; and livelihoods assistance and activities to enable self-reliance. Health, education, socioeconomic and municipal infrastructure support for host communities and refugees in Türkiye is assisted by a joint World Bank-EU Syrians Under Temporary Protection initiative, financed by a €6,000m. Facility for Refugees in Türkiye, which was established in 2015. During the period 2016-May 2023 37,560 Syrians were resettled to the European Union, and during 2014-May 2023 some 21,568 Syrians were transferred from Türkiye to third countries (predominantly to Canada, the USA, the UK and Norway).

Within Syria UNHCR is responsible for the provision of support to IDPs (numbering more than 6.8m. at February 2024) in its leadership areas of CCCM and Shelter, as well as providing NFIs, protection, financial assistance, health, community services, and registration and counselling services. UNHCR has also assisted Syrian IDPs (of whom some 2m. were living in informal settlements and camps) through cash-for-shelter activities. From 2019, in response to the increased flow of arrivals from Islamic State’s former `caliphate’ to al-Hol camp, in al-Hasakah Governorate, eastern Syria, UNHCR and partners established 24-hour response teams to identify and provide urgent assistance to the most vulnerable cases (in particular to unaccompanied children and people requiring immediate medical assistance). They also provided additional large reception tents, more than 8,000 smaller tents, core relief and winter assistance items, cooking areas, and child friendly spaces and schools. In January 2024 the overcrowded al-Hol and Rawj camps, and related facilities were reported to be accommodating more than 48,500 individuals, of whom around 31,600 were reported to be foreign nationals, and a majority children. Syria also accommodates a significant population of stateless people, totalling 160,000 at 31 December 2022.

UNHCR provided emergency assistance to Syria and Türkiye—including through the provision of shelter items and delivery of NFIs and winterization assistance—following the earthquakes that devastated parts of those countries in February 2023. Under broader inter-agency appeals, UNHCR requested US $150m. for Türkiye, and $52m. for Syria.

UNHCR appealed for US $354.4m. to support its operations in conflict-affected Yemen during 2024, where (in February) 21.6m. people were reported to require humanitarian assistance, of whom more than 4.5m. were internally displaced. Yemen was also (as at 30 October 2023) hosting 71,658 refugees, of whom 45,769 were Somalis. Refugees and asylum seekers were mainly accommodated in Aden and in Sana’a (Amanat al-Asimah Governorate). The Office has continued to advocate for resettlement opportunities for the most vulnerable refugees; to extend cash-based interventions; to undertake shelter programmes; to extend legal help to asylum seekers, IDPs, returnees and refugees; to strengthen community resilience; to facilitate durable solutions for IDP returnees; to support the implementation of Yemen’s national displacement policy; and to address continuing incoming migrant flows from the Horn of Africa. Some 38,627 Yemenis were sheltering abroad at 31 December 2022.

UNHCR requested some US $204m. to fund its operations in Iraq during 2024. At 31 December 2023 there were around 1.1m. Iraqi IDPs (in protracted displacement following the 2014-17 Islamic State uprising), of whom around 180,000 were being assisted by UNHCR in 26 formal camps (25 of the camps were in Kurdistan, and one in Ninewa). A process of camp closures had been initiated in August 2019. UNHCR has supported voluntary returns, and advocated with authorities to resolve cases of barred returns and to prevent coerced returns to areas that remain unsafe (owing to the presence of militias, or to contamination by explosive remnants of war and improvised explosive devices, or to the absence of critical infrastructure and destruction of property). There were 4.8m. Iraqi returnees at the end of 2023. Iraq was also hosting 273,258 Syrian refugees (mainly Syrian Kurds). Some 97% of the Syrian refugees are located in Kurdistan, in nine camps and in urban and peri-urban areas. Meanwhile, at 31 December 2022 288,261 refugees of Iraqi origin were residing in other countries.

UNHCR has monitored the Iraqi refugee population in Jordan (which numbered 55,292 at 29 February 2024), to ensure that their protection needs are met, given that recent large inflows of Syrian refugees have placed additional strain on local infrastructures and services.

At the end of 2022 Kuwait was hosting 92,000 people of concern to UNHCR, mainly (stateless) bidoun , as well as Iraqis and Palestinians. Some 70,000 people were registered as stateless in Saudi Arabia at that time.

In May 2012 a regional stakeholders’ conference on Afghanistan endorsed a `Solutions Strategy for Afghan Refugees’ (SSAR), negotiated during 2011 by UNHCR, Afghanistan, Iran and Pakistan, and based on the `pillars’ of voluntary repatriation, sustainable reintegration in Afghanistan, and support for refugee hosting communities On 16 August 2021, in view of the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan, UNHCR issued a formal non-return advisory, aimed at preventing forced returns (including of failed asylum seekers) to that country. Nevertheless, Iran reportedly deported more than 1m. undocumented Afghans throughout that year. The cumulative number of UNHCR-facilitated voluntary repatriations of Afghan refugees from Iran and Pakistan during March 2002-March 2024 totalled around 6.2m. At 30 November 2023 3.5m. Afghan people of concern to UNHCR were in Iran. Most UNHCR-assisted Afghan refugees in Iran (totalling around 750,000) had been issued with official `Amayesh’ identification cards. In 2024 UNHCR was leading an inter-agency response plan that required funding of US $638.8m. and aimed to support 3.2m. Afghan refugees, 1.6m. other vulnerable Afghans, and 2.5m. members of host communities, in Iran and Pakistan. UNHCR has worked to promote the socioeconomic inclusion of Afghan refugees, while pursuing durable solutions.

Libya is both a destination country for economic migrants (who may find informal employment there), and also a principal country of transit for mixed migration flows of refugees and economic migrants attempting to travel to European destinations (the `Central Mediterranean Route’). Libya, in return for financial support from Italy and the EU, agreed in 2017 to intercept vessels carrying migrants and to transfer the passengers to Libyan detention centres. UNHCR maintains a monitoring presence at 12 Mediterranean embarkation points in Libya. At 1 March 2024 there were 61,353 registered refugees and asylum seekers in that country, of whom 35,414 were from Sudan, 11,905 from Syria, and 8,901 from Eritrea. There were also (at 31 August 2023) 125,802 IDPs, 705,426 IDP returnees, and (as at February 2023) 705,746 migrants (of at least 44 nationalities, and including around 5,000 who were being held in detention centres across Libya—to whom the Office has delivered NFIs and hygiene kits). The Office extends international protection services there to unaccompanied and separated children, sick or elderly people, women at risk of trafficking, and to other vulnerable individuals. It works within Libya as well as in neighbouring countries to provide durable solutions and find credible alternatives for refugees and asylum seekers, including resettlement to third countries. UNHCR and IOM jointly lead the UN component of an AU-EU-UN Tripartite Taskforce on the Situation of Migrants and Refugees in Libya (operational since early 2022). Meeting in March 2023 the Taskforce determined to strengthen efforts to support the development of non-discriminatory legal and policy frameworks for migrants and refugees in that country, and urged the Libyan authorities to end arbitrary detention of migrants and refugees. The Taskforce agreed to enhance support for voluntary humanitarian returns from Libya.

UNHCR reported at 1 March 2024 that nearly 68% of refugees and migrants in Libya had either no formal education (29%) or just primary education (nearly 39%); and only 14% had graduated from vocational training or higher education. Some 79% had no occupation in their country of origin.

Under a non-binding Memorandum of Understanding that was concluded in July 2023 between the EU and Tunisia, the EU was to focus investment there on areas that included migration management—prioritizing the local activities of UNHCR and IOM, and the provision of patrol vehicles and equipment.

Under a non-binding Memorandum of Understanding that was concluded in July 2023 between the EU and Tunisia—a favoured point of departure for migrants aiming to reach Italy—the EU was to extend budgetary support to Tunisia, and was to focus investment there on areas that included migration management (with an initial €105m. designated to combating people smuggling, prioritizing the local activities of UNHCR and IOM, and the provision of patrol vehicles and equipment). During two days alone in mid-September some 8,000 migrants who had departed from Tunisia landed on the small Italian island of Lampedusa, which lies around 113 km from the Tunisian coast and 205 km from Sicily.

In March 2016 an EU-Turkey accord entered into effect that provided for failed asylum seekers, and migrants arriving post-20 March in the EU via Greece, who did not apply for asylum in Greece, to be returned to Turkey. Among concessions offered to Turkey in return, EU member states were to resettle one Turkey-based Syrian refugee for every migrant returned to that country from Greece. In accordance with the new agreement (to which UNHCR was not a party) former refugee reception centres were reclassified as detention facilities. In view of UNHCR’s opposition to mandatory detention, it suspended certain of its activities at the former centres, including the provision of transport. UNHCR personnel continued, however, to provide life-saving assistance at coastal locations, to undertake protection monitoring duties, to identify incomers with specific assistance needs, to offer counselling to new arrivals, and to provide information on rights and procedures. During the period 2016-May 2023 37,560 Syrians were resettled to the EU from Türkiye. It was reported in 2023 that Türkiye was no longer readmitting migrants returned from Greece. Of processed first-instance asylum applications made in the EU in 2022, claims by Syrians (and Yemenis) were reportedly among those most likely to be accepted.

Given the lack of progress in achieving a settlement agreement for Western Sahara, UNHCR co-ordinates humanitarian assistance for around 90,000 Sahrawi refugees accommodated, in a protracted situation ongoing since 1975, in five camps in the Tindouf area of Algeria. The refugees are heavily dependent on external assistance as there are few opportunities for income generation in the remote camps. UNHCR provides them with protection and basic relief items. A new Sahrawi Refugee Response Plan, for the period 2024-25, was launched by UNHCR and other UN agencies in November 2023.

int-org-section.heading: Sub-Saharan Africa
int-org-section.p: UNHCR has provided assistance to refugees and IDPs in many parts of the continent where civil conflict, violations of human rights, drought, famine or environmental de­gradation have forced people to flee their home regions. The majority of African refugees and returnees are located in countries that are themselves suffering major economic problems, and often complex, multidimensional emergencies, and are thus unable to provide the basic requirements of the uprooted people. At the end of 2022 there were an estimated 39.7m. people of concern to UNHCR in Africa.

In August 2017 the French, German, Italian and Spanish Governments determined to support Chad and Niger with strengthening their border control capabilities, with a view to stemming the influx of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa into Libya—which is both a destination country for economic migrants (who may find informal employment there) and also a principal country of transit for mixed migration flows of refugees and economic migrants attempting to travel to European destinations.

Persistent severe food insecurity in southern areas of Somalia has exacerbated the longstanding humanitarian crisis in that country. In 2024 UNHCR was attempting to find durable solutions for a Somali IDP population totalling 2,778,453 (at 5 February), of whom 2m. were in south-central Somalia. Furthermore, Somalia was hosting 17,957 registered refugees and 20,506 asylum seekers. UNHCR promotes the assisted voluntary return of IDPs and Somali refugees to their communities of origin, or to other selected integration areas, and the implementation of community-based projects to benefit both returnees and their host communities. Returnees are provided with an assistance package comprising a cash grant in addition to some NFIs, and vouchers for—where available—limited food assistance. During December 2014-31 January 2024 UNHCR assisted 93,721 Somali repatriations. During March 2015-31 January 2024 some 42,984 spontaneous Somali returns from Yemen were recorded (including 951 assisted spontaneous returns since January 2020). Some 923 Somali voluntary repatriations from Kenya were reported during January 2020-January 2024. The Office has continued to provide protection and supply basic services to populations of concern; to extend technical support to the federal authorities on the development of a national policy framework for people of concern; to advocate for equal access to justice; foster local integration, community empowerment, economic inclusion and self-reliance; promote legislation on citizenship; and to provide protection from sexual and gender-based violence and exploitation.

At 31 July 2023 there was an estimated total Somali refugee population of 743,958 sheltering in nearby countries, principally Kenya (hosting 324,130) and Ethiopia (290,073). Meanwhile UNHCR has assisted the Kenyan authorities with strengthening the response capacity of national and local institutions and with finding durable solutions for refugees.
